div.p: "It is ju≈øt with God eternally to ca≈øt off and de≈øtroy ≈øinners."
‚ÄîFor this is the puni≈øhment which the law condemns to; which the things that the law ≈øays, may well ≈øtop every mouth from all manner of objection again≈øt.
The truth of this doctrine may appear by the joint con≈øideration of two things, viz. Man's ≈øinfulne≈øs, and God's ≈øovereignty.
I. It appears from the con≈øideration of man's ≈øinfulne≈øs. And that whether we con≈øider the infinitely evil nature of all ≈øin, or how much ≈øin men are guilty of.

1. If we con≈øider the infinite evil and heinou≈øne≈øs of ≈øin in general, it is not unju≈øt in God to inflict what puni≈øhment is de≈øerved; becau≈øe the very notion of de≈øerving any puni≈øhment is, that it may be ju≈øtly inflicted: A de≈øerved puni≈øhment and a ju≈øt puni≈øhment are the ≈øame thing. To ≈øay that one de≈øerves ≈øuch a puni≈øhment, and yet to ≈øay that he does not ju≈øtly de≈øerve it, is a contradiction; and if he ju≈øtly de≈øerves it; then it may be ju≈øtly inflicted.

Every crime or fault de≈øerves a greater or le≈ø≈øer puni≈øhment, in proportion as the crime it≈øelf is greater or le≈øs. If any fault de≈øerves puni≈øhment, then ≈øo much the greater the fault, ≈øo much the greater is the puni≈øhment de≈øerved. The faulty nature of any thing is the formal ground and rea≈øon of its de≈øert of puni≈øhment; and therefore the more any thing hath of this nature, the more puni≈øhment it de≈øerves. And therefore the terriblene≈øs of the degree of puni≈øhment, let it be never ≈øo terrible, is no argument again≈øt the ju≈øtice of it, if the proportion does but hold between the heinou≈øne≈øs of the crime and the dreadfulne≈øs of the puni≈øhment; ≈øo that if there be any ≈øuch thing as a fault infinitely heinous, it will follow that it is ju≈øt to inflict a puni≈øhment for it that is infinitely dreadful.

A crime is more or le≈øs heinous, according as we are under greater or le≈ø≈øer obligations to the contrary. This is ≈øelf-evident; becau≈øe it is herein that the criminalne≈øs or faultine≈øs of any thing con≈øi≈øts, that it is contrary to what we are obliged or bound to, or what ought to be in us. The crime of one being's de≈øpi≈øing and ca≈øting contempt on another, is proportionably more or le≈øs heinous, as

Our obligation to love, honour, and obey any being, is in proportion to his loveline≈øs, honourablene≈øs, and authority; for that is the very meaning of the words. But God is a being infinitely lovely, becau≈øe he hath infinite excellency and beauty. To have infinite excellency and beauty, is the ≈øame thing as to have infinite loveline≈øs.
